nodes.bodyText:
What is res.getValue() here? convertValue isn't an efficient operation as it will convert the passed object back into JSON and deserialize it again targeting the new Class type.
We should validate what type is being returned here.
What we returned is Object, we convert Object to SearchDocument
What we do here is to serialize Object to json, and desrialize to map. I did not find any API which can shortcut the process.

I'm okay with this as it follows what the service will be doing. It is a little concerning though as we are implicitly mutating passed customer value, so we need to make sure this is documented strongly somewhere.
Sure. Will add JavaDoc.
Since Date is in UTC, the mutation is not resulting in data-loss. So, it's okay to set the timezone to UTC and format the string.
SimpleDateFormat has some shortage of converting am/pm. I convert the date value to offsetDateTime to guarantee the accuracy.
Date is assumed UTC but is that a contractual agreement in the model? Either way this is the best option we have in supporting it so I'm good with it.
Can we make format a static property on the class, it is the same during every call. Check if it is thread safe before making the change though.

SimpleDateFormat is not thread safe. It will trigger the spotbugs
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/6840803/why-is-javas-simpledateformat-not-thread-safe
Why was the logic here changed to eagerly call the deserializer?
This is needed for every block. Just tried to minimize the code with local var.
Why was this logic flipped?
The order does not make any differences.
Are we good for using the generic Map.class or do we need to use a JavaType which explicitly determines to use Map<String, Object>.

I'm a little confused on the decimal to String conversion, is there any reason we can't use %+02f anymore in the String.format call? Are we looking to get additional units of precision in the decimal part?
I am trying to replicate the format service return.
Don't need to call toString here as the formatting function should implicitly do that.
I don't think these tests are testing different concepts as Date has no concept of time zone.
I will rename this. I am trying to test two different ways of providing date, one is intended to use UTC date, one did not specify anything.
This date format is used in multiple places. Consider making this a string constant.
Return the obj here instead of having empty catch block.
Is this required? module, which has the date deserializer, is registered to the mapper in the next line.
Here we register both serializer and deserializer for java.utl.Date type
Set the locale to Locale.ROOT.
isValid should also check that coordinates.get(0) and coordinates.get(1) are not null?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -63,6 +70,7 @@ public static GeoPoint create(double latitude, double longitude, CoordinateSyste
      *
      * @return true if valid, false if invalid
      */
+    @JsonIgnore
     public boolean isValid() {
         return coordinates != null && coordinates.size() == 2
             && coordinates.get(0) >= -180.0 && coordinates.get(0) <= 180.0

nodes.bodyText: Should this be a common class in azure-core? Iso8601 seems like a common format to deserialize?

DateTimeSerializer is supposed to deserialize and deserialize this format.. should the fix be in there?
https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-java/blob/master/sdk/core/azure-core/src/main/java/com/azure/core/util/serializer/DateTimeSerializer.java#L18

Search allows to upload user-defined documents with any date classes.
The link you have is to support Joda time (OffsetDateTime, LocalDateTime etc).
What we are trying to do here is to support old date lib (java.util.Date)
We agreed to put serializer to search only, since Search has specific format and time zone requirement.
As discussed, these serializers are Jackson specific and may have to go into a separate pluggable module in a follow-up PR. This will allow us to support Gson serializers too.
